reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I've been going to Shenandoah National Park since I was a small child back in the 1960s. Back then, we piled into the station wagon, and dad pulled the family camper up to Lewis Mountain where we all had a grand time. Later I graduated to backpacking and have returned again and again to cover the trails and sleep in the backcountry. Many times I've passed through Big Meadows area. The Appalachian Trail literally runs directly behind the lodge, and as I've walked past carrying my shelter and food with me, I've thought, "Those poor souls who can't get into the wilderness and must stay in hotels!"
reviews.title: We can't wait to return!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My husband is not a camper, and he has refused to ever camp in the wilderness with me. Finally, after 23 years of marriage, I broke down and decided to make a reservation at Big Meadows Lodge in order to share this gorgeous park with my husband. We pulled up to the lovely main inn on a Friday night after traveling 20 white-knuckle miles on the Skyline Drive through rain and thick, thick fog. Know that if you have rain in the valley as you approach the mountains, those very rain clouds will be sitting directly on the mountain road when you drive up. It was impossible to see more than a few feet ahead of us in the dense fog. When we finally reached the lodge, it was a very welcome sight. This pretty stone lodge was nestled in the trees, warm lights gleaming through the windows. Our check-in was prompt and friendly. We parked and walked a short way to our room in the Rapidan Building. While the building itself is not very attractive, looking something like a painted cinder-block motel from the 1970's, the room was recently remodeled, with lovely wood floors, and new, bright furnishings of a rustic style. There was a cathedral ceiling, and the walls and ceiling were covered in beautiful paneling. There was no phone, which was wonderful for me. We did have a new television with cable connection for a few channels. We watched it briefly each day to get weather reports and some news. We also had a/c and heat, but this particular weekend was on the chilly side, so no a/c was noted. We had a lovely little balcony with standard plastic chairs and plastic table, as well. The bathroom was clean, though a bit dated. I also have to say that the walls were a bit thin in this building. We could hear our neighbors muffled conversations, but that wasn't too bothersome.
reviews.title: Great atmosphere and scenery

likes.liked: — The views, the ambiance and atmosphere, the rustic quality

reviews.text: We admired our room briefly and then quickly headed back to the main lodge to get some food after our long trip. Unfortunately, we arrived near 9:00 p.m., and the dining room was closing. But the "Tap Room" was open downstairs for light fair and entertainment. The room itself reminded me of my parents "rumpus room" in our basement growing up. Paneling, dropped ceilings, nondescript government issue tables and chairs. But the atmosphere was friendly and festive. Three park rangers were providing excellent music, some of which was produced on an amazing 77-year-old steel guitar with old-fashioned modulator. Our bartender, Debbie, got into the act, as well, belting out Patsy Cline songs like nobody's business! We also enjoyed delicious bowls of chili, and some good bourbon, as well. It was almost like going to a grown-up summer camp that night.
reviews.title: Oasis at 3000 feet
Just ate here -- food was lousy, service appalling
reviews.text: The following day, we enjoyed an excellent breakfast in the dining room. I had the hiker's breakfast, which included egg beaters and a delicious vegetable hash. The blackberry jam was sooo delicious, as were the biscuits. My husband enjoyed a large omelet with all the fixings. The coffee was a bit weak, as it was at our next breakfast. This was a disappointment, because just the summer before I had walked over from the campground for breakfast at the lodge, and thought the coffee was the best I had ever had.

There were four couples in our group and we stayed in the motel rooms at Big Meadows Lodge on July 6th and 7th, 2007. The rooms have been renovated since last year and were a pleasant surprise. We have stayed here a number of times in the past and the upgrades made the stay more enjoyable. The following were all new: wooden floors, knotty pine type beds, mattresses, combination dresser/closet, chairs, cable television (not that you should spend much time in the room). Another new addition are the window heater/airconditioners (in the past, there was no air conditioners that we remember). There are no telephones in the rooms, but who needs them. You must remember that you are staying in a National Park and should not expect five star accomodations; comfortable rooms are what you do get. We have stayed in a number of lodgings in our National Parks and this compares favorable to them (it is not quite the Ahwanee in Yosemite, though). The food is average and what you would expect in a National Park restaurant. The food is okay and the price is on the high side but you have to consider the alternatives: eat at another restaurant, Skyland Lodge, which is in the park, bring your own food (which we did the first night there as we had gotten campsites to cook our food on a charcoal fire) or eat in Luray or Front Royal which are both outside Shenandoah National Park.
reviews.title: Remodeled motel rooms were great

likes.liked: — They had been renovated from last year.

reviews.text: In the daytime the gnats were a little bothersome so bring an insect spray or wipes that contain an insect repellant. The black bear were active during this time frame and we saw three of them over the weekend. But back to the review, if you have stayed at Big Meadows in previous years, you will be pleasantly surprised at the renovations. The Lodge is a great place to stay and use as a base for hiking, climbing and enjoying nature in a National Park.
reviews.title: Great place to get away

likes.liked: — Views, updated room, nature, convenient location right in park

reviews.text: Stayed in rooms 94-95 (connecting) on the first floor of the Rapidan Building. This building has a view of the valley. These rooms have been updated with: satellite TV, a/c (which we did not need, even in July - it was in the high 70's/low 80's during the day and 50's/60's at night when you are in the room), new wood or Pergo type flooring, new furniture made of light colored large pine, all new woodsy-themed linens, leather (pleather?) chairs. Still no phones in rooms. Nice wood panelling, which I think was original. Much nicer than expected. 100 times better inside that you would think looking at the outside! Two windows have screens to get the fresh mountain air. A few notes:

Bathrooms have not really been updated except for walls, yet were surprisingly spotless. Maybe the porcelain had been refinished? The old light fixture made it clear that the bathrooms had not been remodeled.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We booked our one-night stay from abroad, by internet, using the Lodge's website (Skyline Resort also on the same website, visitshenandoah.com) and this worked reliably. Note that the charge for your accommodation is made, in full, at the time of booking.
reviews.title: Beautiful location, very enjoyable stay.
Excellent character-filled accommodation
reviews.text: Arrived and departed in thick fog, which was disappointing, but at least the lodge and the room were really attractive. The room - built all of wood - had a heavy and attractive scent of wood, was spacious and attractive, very smartly presented, and despite the presence of the excellent new TV screen, managed to maintain its traditional air of country dignity. View of woodlands out the back window over the balcony, and deer appeared in the fog the following morning.
The lodge is equally charming. The food isn't that great, but it's OK, and the overall experience is enhanced by the beautiful wooden dining room, and log burning fires.
reviews.title: A very baeutiful lodge, with an incredible view!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: There are few places you can stay that are well maintained, comfortable and have resisted being another run of the mill hotel. This lodge is wonderful, it's so pristine and secluded, but in fact just 90 min (or so) from DC. Sure the food isn't the high point of staying here, the views and fresh air are. The rooms look like they were recently redone, and they were clean, nice wood-timber furniture.
reviews.title: Loved Big Meadows

reviews.text: Staying so late in the season also was great as there were no crowds, little traffic on Skyline Drive and it was very nice to take day trips
reviews.title: Pricey but convenient
